"Note: The combination ""crown +human legs"" appears seven times in Heisig. In four cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) the crown is above the human legs, and in the other three cases (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. The naming is inconsistent, so I call the first pattern ""Miss World"" (who is wearing a crown she won due to her attractive human legs) and the second ""garter"" (one human leg passes through the crown and wears it as a garter)."	1425.0	35.0	Fingers . . . paper punch . . . tree. It's actually not マ + 男, but rather, this is an abbreviated form of 甬 + 力, which gives it more of a meaning of 'path of power' or 'run through with power' or something like that. But if you don't care about the real origins and formation, either way of thinking of it works ^-^. To have courage is to run through (甬) with power (力). When that happens, a マ becomes a man (男)."	1 N1

"Just a comment on Erikkusan's story: Although one of the pronunciations of this kanji is ""atsui"" this isn't the atsui that you feel in Tokyo in August, (which is Frame 1260's ""sultry' 暑). Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).	You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your´s and your neighbours´ garden. But unfortunately, it´s not long until your rake splits in two.	1723.0	41.0	At the top we have the animal horns and the single horizontalstroke to give them something to hang onto. Below that, we seeone rake with two handles. Finally, we see a pair of strokessplitting away from each of the handles, indicating that theyare both splitting under the pressure. The composite picture isof someone holding down two jobs concurrently, using thesame kit of tools to move in two different directions and endingup in a mess. Take the time to find this sense in the kanji andit will be easy to remember, despite initial appearances.	"<img src=""兼.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_兼.png""/>"	At the top we have the animal horns (䒑) and the single horizontal stroke to give them something to hang onto. Below that, we see one rake (肀) with two handles (丨丨). Finally, we see a pair of strokes splitting away from each of the handles (ハ) , indicating that they are both splitting under the pressure. The composite picture is of someone holding down two jobs concurrently, using the same kit of tools to move in two different directions and ending up in a mess. Take the time to find this sense in the kanji and it will be easy to remember, despite initial appearances.	4 N1, 1 N0

In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you´ll get the stroke order exactly correct."	The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... In case youshould have any trouble, though, you might doodle with theshapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference inthe stroke order of the two facing doors. The gates usuallyserve as an enclosure, and are written before whatever it isthey enclose. 倉	ソウ	くら		godown, warehouse, storehouse, cellar, treasury		倉庫(そうこ): storehouse; warehouse; godown	1.0	4	1114.0	人: person 口: mouth	10.0	人	9.0	2.0	ひと・にんべん・ひとやね	(none)	象形 Pictographic	godown	A godown is a dockside warehouse. This is actually a meeting of large doors and mouths. The stroke order is the same as door, not gates, just with the top stroke moved down into the now larger door.	Note: this is not gate but actually a variation of door and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.	1758.0	42.0	The single gate is used here not in order to represent one gate,but many of them, indeed a meeting of gates. Add mouth (as anentrance here) and you end up with godown. That should helpkeep this character distinct from storehouse (frame 589).	"<img src=""倉.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_倉.png""/>"	"The godown is like a dockside warehouse located in Asia. The goods stored there are usually piled up on pallets really high, and thus they have to ""godown"" before they can be taken outside. There is only one door (戸) that acts as a mouth (口) to allow people and things to enter and have a meeting (亼)."	2 N1, 1 N0

緯	イ	よこいと、ぬき		horizontal, woof, left & right, latitude		経緯(いきさつ): (1) details; particulars; whole story; sequence of events; chronology; circumstances; how it started; how things got this way (2) longitude and latitude (3) warp and weft; warp and woof<br>緯度(いど): latitude (nav.)	1.0	S	1430.0	糸: thread 韋: tanned leather radical (no. 178)	16.0	糸	120.0	6.0	いと・いとへん	(none)	形声 Phonetic	horizontal	The thread that holds the locket around my neck is choker-length so it stays horizontal.	"Hint : this kanji also means ""latitude"", which are the horizontal lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 ""black ink"" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his ""thread locket"" to mark horizontal lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark horizontal lines. Imagine the ""thread-locket"" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread."	1774.0	42.0	Thread . . . locket. By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! 宇	ウ		いえ, たか, ひろ, ひろし	eaves, roof, house, heaven		宇宙(うちゅう): universe; cosmos; space	2.0	6	883.0	宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40) 于: going; from	6.0	宀	40.0	3.0	うかんむり	(none)	形声 Phonetic	eaves	Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.	Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.	1785.0	43.0	House . . . potato. No luck: it weights too much.	"This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol "">"" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means ""two much"" (more than 2) or ""two little"". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!)."	1786.0	43.0	Umbrella . . . potato . . . little. The last stroke of potato and thefirst of little coincide in this character.	"<img src=""余.gif""/>"	"* Since the phrase ""too much"" is overly abstract, we shall takethe image of a scale whose indicator spins round and roundon the dial because too much weight has been set on it. It willhelp to use this image in learning the kanji itself."	"<img src=""ex_余.png""/>"	"This is the kanji for あまり, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol "">"" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella (𠆢) component, and using two (二) and little (小) for the potato (于) primitive. So, this kanji either means ""two (二) much (>)"" or ""two (二) little (小)""."	2 N3, 1 N2, 3 N1

They´re basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...	"Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of ""The Awl and the Sabre"". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : ""The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can´t use the sabre.""."	1801.0	43.0	Awl . . . saber. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as companion (#19), friend (#704), consort (#1203) and comrade (#1637). (The extrashort stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the characterfor twenty.) All one needs to add is some image of sweetcakes or breads carried in the basket, and the union of pictureand meaning is complete. Take care not to confuse with candy(frame 1122).	"<img src=""甘.gif""/>"	* As a primitive, the pictograph´s meaning of a wicker basket isused, a small one like the kind used for picnics.	"<img src=""ex_甘.png""/>"	Sweet twenty(廿)-one(一). The next sweet number after sweet sixteen.	7 N1, 5 N0

"Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a rowing boat. In a rowing boat people sit in rows, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for ""rowboat"" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for ""rowboat"" has a generic meaning of ""a small boat"". In any case, the kanji for ""rowboat"" will not appear as a primitive in the book."	1924.0	47.0	This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of thekanji for stand. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes,you will see how this is done.	"<img src=""並.gif""/>"	* The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji,but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shapethis element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you willmeet in this book. When it appears beneath its relativeprimitive, the top two strokes are omitted, and the first horizontalstroke is doubled up with the bottom horizontalstroke of the element above it, wherever possible: o. atop itsrelative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it doesnot, the top three strokes are removed and all of them arereplaced below the primitive´s bottom line: p. We shallacknowledge this latter transformation by changing itsmeaning to upside down in a row.	"<img src=""ex_並.png""/>"	This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing (立) in a row.	1 N2, 1 N1

僕	ボク	しもべ		me, I (male)		僕(ぼく): (1) I; me (2) you (used addressing young children) (3) manservant<br>僕(しもべ): servant; manservant; menial	1.0	S	1236.0	人: person 菐: None	14.0	人	9.0	2.0	ひと・にんべん・ひとやね	(none)	形声 Phonetic	me	Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.	"Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it´s the kanji for ""boku."" Males usually use either ""boku"" or ""ore"" (instead of ""watashi"") to refer themselves. ""Boku"" is slightly boyish and soft; ""ore"" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use ""ore"" -- but when he´s one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to ""boku"" when he pleads ""come on baby, it´s ME!""."	1933.0	47.0	"This key word is yet another synonym for ""I,"" somewhat morefamiliar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men useto refer to themselves. Its elements: person . . . husbands . . . ina row upside down."	"<img src=""僕.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_僕.png""/>"	"If Mr. T (亻) and the fat viking husband (菐) spoke Japanese, would they use ""watashi"" (私), ""boku"" (僕) or ""ore"" (俺)? Well, 私 is too formal, so no. 僕 is more colloquial and humble. 俺 is rough and tough (you would expect them to use this). However, here they're drinking beer in the bar with the viking horned helmets (丵) when the husband(夫)'s wife storms inside. Totally ashamed, both of them use ""Boku"" (hence why this is the kanji). ""僕 pity the fool who gets married to a viking wife!"""	none

民	ミン	たみ	ひと, み	people, nation, subjects		国民(こくみん): nation; nationality; people; citizen<br>市民(しみん): citizen; townspeople<br>住民(じゅうみん): citizens; inhabitants; residents; population<br>民間(みんかん): private; civilian; civil; popular; folk; unofficial<br>民主(みんしゅ): (1) democracy; popular sovereignty (2) democratic<br>民族(みんぞく): people; race; nation<br>人民(じんみん): people; public<br>農民(のうみん): farmers; peasants<br>庶民(しょみん): masses; common people<br>移民(いみん): (1) emigration; immigration (2) emigrant; immigrant<br>植民地(しょくみんち): (1) colony (2) colonial<br>民謡(みんよう): folk song; popular song<br>民宿(みんしゅく): private home providing lodging for travelers (travellers)<br>民俗(みんぞく): folk customs; folkways; ethnic customs	4.0	4	28.0	氏: family name; surname; clan	5.0	氏	83.0	4.0	うじ	(none)	象形 Pictographic	people	All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.	"How many of you know what ""vox populi"" means?"	1976.0	49.0	"In place of the drop at the start of the character for family name,we have a mouth, which makes you think of the ""vox populi."""	"<img src=""民.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_民.png""/>"	"In this character for people, in place of the drop (丶) at the start of the character for family name (氏), we have a mouth (口), which makes you think of the ""vox populi."" Vox populi means ""voice of the people"" referring to people as nation. This is often used as an abbreviation of the phrase ""Vox populi, vox dei"" which means ""voice of the people, voice of god"", referring to the godlike power people have over their government. In this context, I think of this character as an angry mob that is rebelling against it's corrupt government, hence we have big mouths (口) which call out the unwanted officials by their family name (氏), and they are waving national flags (尸) in protest."	1 N3

Company directors (司) are the worst, making up new words (訁) by verbing nouns and nouning verbs. ""please action that"", ""what is the take-home from that?""."	none

舟	シュウ	ふね、ふな-、-ぶね		boat, ship			2.0	S	1786.0	舟: boat, boat radical (no. 137)	6.0	舟	137.0	6.0	ふね・ふねへん	(none)	象形 Pictographic	boat	I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. 繭	ケン	まゆ、きぬ		cocoon			1.0	S	2495.0	艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140) 冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13) 糸: thread 虫: insect; bug; temper	18.0	糸	120.0	6.0	いと・いとへん	(none)	会意 Compound Ideographic	cocoon	This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.	The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.	2025.0	51.0	Though it´s a good thing that the primitive for cocoon has beenradically abbreviated from this, its full form as a kanji, the storyit holds is a charming one. The silkworm (insect) eats the leavesof the mulberry bush (the flowers), digests them and transformsthem into thread with which it spins about itself, in mysticwisdom, its own coffin (the hood). The dividing line thatseparates the two elements helps the picture of the little wormcutting itself off from contact with the outside world, but as acharacter stroke, it is a clear exception.	"<img src=""繭.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_繭.png""/>"	"Though it's a good thing that the primitive for cocoon has been radically abbreviated from this, its full form as a kanji, the story it holds is a charming one. The silkworm (insect 虫) eats the leaves of the mulberry bush (the flowers 艹), digests them and transforms them into thread (糹) with which it spins about itself, in mystic wisdom, its own coffin (the hood 冂). The dividing line (丨) that separates the two elements helps the picture of the little worm cutting itself off from contact with the outside world, but as a character stroke, it is a clear exception."	none

She shouldn´t have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend´s schemes.	"This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling ""Eureka! Eureka!"" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29."	2033.0	51.0	The technique for sinking used in this kanji is unique. Ratherthan the biblical image of tying a millstone about the victim´sneck, here we see a crown tied about one leg before the unfortunateparty is tossed into the water.	"<img src=""沈.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_沈.png""/>"	"A dumb blondie hears Archimedes' story for the first time and tries it in her bathroom sink. She fills it with water (氵) and puts a garter (冘) inside. The garter (冘) however floats. ""Boring!"" she thinks, and unplugs the sink, draining the water (氵). The garter (冘) swirls in circles and she claps cheerfully, until the garter (冘) sinks through the drain too! garter: a band worn around the leg to keep up a stocking or sock."	none

呉	ゴ	く.れる、くれ	ぐ	give, do something for		呉れる(くれる): to give; to let one have; to do for one; to be given<br>呉れ呉れも(くれぐれも): repeatedly; sincerely; earnestly	1.0	S	1729.0	口: mouth 八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)	7.0	口	30.0	3.0	くち・くちへん	(none)	会意 Compound Ideographic	give	"Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, ""My uncle gave me this watch."" Following -て form of another verb, means ""to do the favor of"": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, ""Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?"" Usu. written in hiragana."	I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!	2046.0	51.0	The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult,because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The mouth and tool are already familiar.	"<img src=""呉.gif""/>"		"<img src=""ex_呉.png""/>"	As a present, I gave my dentist a hand-crank () tool (具) for spreading mouths (口). He was so happy since it makes his job easier.	1 N3, 2 N1

藩	ハン			clan, enclosure			1.0	S	1896.0	艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140) 潘: water in which rice has been washed	18.0	艸	140.0	6.0	くさ・くさかんむり	(none)	形声 Phonetic	clan	This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans´ location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.	In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers.	2061.0	52.0	Flowers . . . water . . . dice. Afar, a boy is SITTING while watching the workers reSHAPING the environment. So, in similar fashion, your feelings, and the shape (彡) of your face, go from happy to really gloomy, and now you truly understand why this place is called the gloomy grove (林).	none

If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail ""feathers"". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though."	"The top part is half a comb (see frame 1920) with an extra vertical stroke to account for a sturdier version used to comb a horse mane. As a primitive I used the theme of the Trojan Horse. Not the modern computer viruses, but the large wooden horse which led to the demise of Troy and of the Trojans. Either its size (much greater than a live horse), or the fact that it conceals things into its belly, will set it appart from the horse primitive that came in frame 568 (""noon"")."	2132.0	54.0	Let the extra vertical stroke in the mane combine with the firstvertical stroke to give an image of the horse´s long neck. Theonly odd thing is the tail feathers at the end, but that shouldpresent a good image to remember the character by. The factthat the last stroke of mane and the first of tail feathers coincideshould no longer surprise you. ""Baka"" can be written in katakana or in kanji with 馬鹿. The theory of its origin states that there was once a king who was so dumb that he asked for a horse (馬), someone brought him a deer (鹿), and he couldn't tell the difference. Well I find it insulting that a language can't come up with a worse insult than that!"	none

虎	コ	とら	たけ	tiger, drunkard		虎(トラ): (1) tiger (Panthera tigris) (2) drunk person	1.0	S	1653.0	虍: tiger spots; mottled; tiger or tiger crown radical (no. 141) 八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)	8.0	虍	141.0	6.0	とら・とらがしら・とらかんむり	(none)	象形 Pictographic	tiger	Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn´t like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard).	"Tigger, the tiger, (from Pooh stories) is happy to have found a magic wand. Using it he can bounce up to a the top of a cliff, seven times as high as some human legs could bounce. Tigger thinks ""Its great to be a tiger!"	2145.0	54.0	The kanji in this frame recalls the famous Bengali fable aboutthe group of magicians (the magic wand) who decided to makea tiger. It seems that each of them knew how to make one partof the beast, so they pooled their talents and brought all thepieces (diced into pieces) together, at which point the fabricatedtiger promptly ate its makers up (the bodiless humanlegs). Whatever the parable´s significance for modern civilizationand its arsenals, it should help with this kanji.Oh yes, we should not forget that cliff-like element. Think ofit as an abbreviation of the primitive for zoo (the first andfourth strokes, actually), in order to fit the tiger somewhereinto the picture. In fact, the abbreviation is perfectly logical,since the bottom elements usurp the room for the rest of theprimitive for zoo.	"<img src=""虎.gif""/>"	* As a primitive element itself, the human legs are also swallowedup, but the meaning of tiger is kept, and the wholeserves as a roof for what comes beneath, , giving the tigersomething else to eat.	"<img src=""ex_虎.png""/>"	"The kanji in this frame recalls the famous Bengali fable about the group of magicians (the magic wand 卜) who decided to make a tiger. It seems that each of them knew how to make one part of the beast, so they pooled their talents and brought all the pieces (diced 七 into pieces) together, at which point the fabricated tiger promptly ate its makers up (the bodiless human legs 儿). Whatever the parable's significance for modern civilization and its arsenals, it should help with this kanji. Oh yes, we should not forget that cliff-like element. Think of it as an abbreviation of the primitive for zoo (the first and fourth strokes, actually), in order to fit the tiger somewhere into the picture. In fact, the abbreviation is perfectly logical, since the bottom elements usurp the room for the rest of the primitive for zoo."	none

Santa´s reindeer, Rudolf, opens a nightclub in a cave. It´s popular with all the deer and reindeer in the world. The cave speciality is a salad w/ dressing on the side. There is no other deer club that can compare. How many other deer nightclubs are there?	2154.0	54.0	"Drawn on the walls of a complex of caves near Niaux in southernFrance are a number of animal likenesses dating from theUpper Paleolithic period. Among them we find pictures ofdeer, some of them showing men in deer masks. By comparingtheir drawings to real deer, Stone Age people hoped to acquirepower over the animal in the hunt; and by comparing themselvesto the deer, to take on that animal´s characteristics. Buttime has ""double-locked"" (the extra stroke through the elementfor lock) the real secret of this art form from us, and we canonly surmise such meanings. But more important than theenigmas of the troglodytic mind is the way in which caves, adouble-lock, and comparing gives us the kanji for deer."	"<img src=""鹿.gif""/>"	* As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated much the same as thetiger was: the lower element is dropped to leave room for areplacement: . Its meaning, however, remains the same.There are a very few cases (see frame 2002) in which there isno abbreviation. When this happens, we may keep the imagesuggested by the above explanation: painting of a deer.	"<img src=""ex_鹿.png""/>"	"Drawn on the walls of a complex of caves (广) near Niaux in southern France are a number of animal likenesses dating from the Upper Paleolithic period. Among them we find pictures of deer, some of them showing men in deermasks. By comparing (比) their drawings to real deer, Stone Age people hoped to acquire power over the animal in the hunt; and by comparing (比) themselves to the deer, to take on that animal's characteristics. But time has locked with a ""double-key"" (龷 + |) the real secret of this art form from us, and we can only surmise such meanings. But more important than the enigmas of the troglodytic mind is the way in which caves (广), a double-key (龷 + |), and comparing (比) gives us the kanji for deer."	5 N1, 6 N0

冫	Ice	426.1				When water loses heat, it becomes ice. Hence when the radical water (氵) loses a stroke, it becomes the radical ice (冫)

0	cha ikenai / ja ikenai	ちゃいけない・じゃいけない	must not do (spoken Japanese)	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb <s>て</s></td><td>ちゃだめ<br>ちゃいけない<br>ちゃいけません</td></tr><tr><td>Verb <s>で</s></td><td>じゃダメ<br>じゃいけない<br>じゃいけません</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"寝る前にスマホを見<span class=""color"">ちゃダメ</span>よ。"	ねるまえにスマホをみちゃだめよ。	"You shouldn't look at your smartphone before going to bed."	"ここはきけんなので、入っ<span class=""color"">ちゃダメ</span>だよ。"	ここはきけんなので、はいっちゃだめだよ。	"This area is dangerous, so you're not allowed to enter."	"やっ<span class=""color"">ちゃいけない</span>ことをやっちゃった。"	やっちゃいけないことをやっちゃった。	"I did something I shouldn't have..."	"自信をなくし<span class=""color"">ちゃいけません</span>！"	じしんをなくしちゃいけません！	"You mustn't lose confidence!"	"そんなに授業をさぼっ<span class=""color"">ちゃダメ</span>よ。"	そんなにじゅぎょうをさぼっちゃだめよ。	"You shouldn't skip class so much."	"彼を信用し<span class=""color"">ちゃいけない</span>。"	かれをしにょうしちゃいけない。	We cannot trust him.	"赤信号をむしし<span class=""color"">ちゃいけません</span>！"	あかしんごうをむししちゃいけません。	You must not ignore red lights!	"野菜を食べるまでデザートを食べ<span class=""color"">ちゃいけない</span>よ。"	やさいをたべるまでデザートをたべちゃいけないよ。	No eating dessert until you finish eating your vegetables.	"子どもの前に悪いことばを言っ<span class=""color"">ちゃいけません</span>。"	こどものまえにわるいことばをいっちゃいけません。	We must not say bad words in front of children.	"２０歳未満の人はお酒を飲ん<span class=""color"">じゃいけません</span>。"	はたちみまんのひとはおさけをのんじゃいけません。	People under the age of 20 cannot drink alcohol.	
1	da / desu	だ / です	to be (am, is, are, were, used to)	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>present<br>affirmative</td><td>だ (casual)<br>です (polite)</td></tr><tr><td>past<br>affirmative</td><td>だった (casual)<br>でした (polite)</td></tr><tr><td>present<br>negative</td><td>じゃない<br>ではない<br>じゃありません<br>ではありません</td></tr><tr><td>past<br>negative</td><td>じゃなかった<br>ではなかった<br>じゃありませんでした<br>ではありませんでした</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"今日は暑い<span class=""color"">です</span>ね。"	きょうはあついですね。	"It's pretty hot today, isn't it?"	"かれは私の友だち<span class=""color"">です</span>。"	かれはわたしのともだちです。	He is my friend.	"日本の文化が好き<span class=""color"">です</span>。"	にほんのぶんかがすきです。	I like Japanese culture	"昔はサッカーが趣味<span class=""color"">だった</span>が、今はやっていない。"	むかしはサッカーがしゅみだったが、いまはやっていない。	"Soccer used to be my hobby, but I don't play anymore."																			
2	dake	だけ	only; just; as much as~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (dictionary form)</td><td rowspan=""4"">だけ</td></tr><tr><td>Noun</td></tr><tr><td>な-adjective + な</td></tr><tr><td>い-adjective</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"私の持っているお金はこれ<span class=""color"">だけ</span>だ。"	わたしのもっているおかねはこれだけだ。	This is all the money I have..	"ちょっと見ている<span class=""color"">だけ</span>です。"	ちょっとみっているだけです。	"I'm just looking around."	"好きじゃない食べ物はトマト<span class=""color"">だけ</span>だ。"	すきじゃないたべものはトマトだけだ。	The only food I dislike are tomatoes.	"ただ話していた<span class=""color"">だけ</span>です。"	ただはなしていただけです。	I was just speaking.	"問題はそれ<span class=""color"">だけ</span>だと思うかい？"	もんだいはそれだけだとおもう？	"You think that's all there is to this problem?"	"私は一人<span class=""color"">だけ</span>でできます。"	わたしはひとりだけでできます。	I can do it (just) by myself.	"出来る<span class=""color"">だけ</span>新しい漢字を勉強したい。"	できるだけあたらしいかんじをべんきょうしたい。	I want to study as much new kanji as possible.	"その女の子はただ泣く<span class=""color"">だけ</span>だった。"	そのおんなのこはただなくだけだった。	That little girl did nothing but cry.	"彼女が信頼できるのは彼<span class=""color"">だけ</span>だ。"	かのじょがしんらいできるのはかれだけだ。	He is the only one that she can trust.				
3	darou	だろう	I think; it seems; probably; right?	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (dictionary form)</td><td rowspan=""4"">だろう</td></tr><tr><td>Noun</td></tr><tr><td>な-adjective</td></tr><tr><td>い-adjective</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"彼はもうすぐ来る<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。"	かれはもうすぐくるだろう。	He should be coming any moment now.	"そう<span class=""color"">だろう</span>と思ったよ。"	そうだろうとおもった。	I thought (figured) as much.	"明日はたぶん雨が降る<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。空に雲がたくさんあるから。"	あしたはたぶんあめがふるだろう。そらにくもがたくさんあるから。	"It will likely rain tomorrow.. There's a lot of clouds in the sky now.."	"間違いない<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。"	まちがいないだろう。	"Surely there's no mistake."	"たぶんこの雨は１時間ぐらいでやむ<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。"	たぶんこのあめはいちじかんぐらいでやむだろう。	This rain will probably be over in about an hour or so.	"あそこにいる人は誰<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。"	あそこにいるひとはだれだろう。	I wonder who that person is over there.	"この肉は、もう食べないほうがいい<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。もう悪くなってしまった。"	このにくは、もうたべないほうがいいだろう。もうわるくなってしまった。	"It's probably best to not eat this meat. It's already gone bad.."	"どうして日本の夏はこんなに暑いん<span class=""color"">だろう</span>。"	どうしてにほんのなつはこんなにあついんだろう。	Why is Summer in Japan so hot..?							
4	de	で	in; at; on; by; with; via	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Noun</td><td>で</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"じてんしゃ<span class=""color"">で</span>行きます。"	じてんしゃをつかう	I will go by bicycle. 8	doushite	どうして	why; for what reason; how	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>can be used mid-sentence or to start new sentence</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"<span class=""color"">どうして</span>来ないの？"	どうしてこないの？	"Why aren't you coming?" 9	douyatte	どうやって	how; in what way; by what means​	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>can be used at beginning or mid-sentence</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"駅まで<span class=""color"">どうやって</span>行きますか。"	えきまでどうやっていきますか。	How can I get to the station? "リサさんは毎日<span class=""color"">どうやって</span>学校へ来ますか。"	リサさんはまいにちどうやってがっこうへきますか。	Lisa, how do you come to school every day?	"<span class=""color"">どうやって</span>彼女と出会ったのですか。"	どうやってかのじょとであったのですか。	How did you meet her?	"あなたは<span class=""color"">どうやって</span>漢字を覚えますか。"	あなたはどうやってかんじをおぼえますか。	How do you memorize kanji? "私は彼が<span class=""color"">どうやって</span>一人でそれをやったのか知らない。"	わたしはかれがどうやってひとりでそれをやったのかしらない。	"I don't know how he did that all alone."							
10	ga	が	subject marker; however; but ~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Usage 1: subject marker<br>subject + が</td></tr><tr><td>Usage 2: however; but<br>Sentence 1 + が + Sentence 2</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"明日は雨<span class=""color"">が</span>降る。"	あしたはあめがふる。	It is going to rain tomorrow.	"仕方<span class=""color"">が</span>ない。"	しかたがない。	It cannot be helped. (a common expression in Japanese)	"コンビニ<span class=""color"">が</span>近くにあります。"	コンビニがちかくにあります。	There is a convenience store nearby.	"彼は借金<span class=""color"">が</span>ある。"	かれはしゃっきんがある。	He is in debt.	"今日は、やること<span class=""color"">が</span>たくさんある。"	きょうは、やることがたくさんある。	There are a lot of things to do today.	"彼は金はある<span class=""color"">が</span>、バカな男だ。"	かれはかねはあるが、ばかなおとこだ。	"He has money, but he's a stupid man."	"私は日本語を話すことはできます<span class=""color"">が</span>、読むことはできません。"	わたしはにほんごをはなすことはできますが、よむことはできません。	I can speak Japanese, but I am not able to read it.	"このカメラを買いたいです<span class=""color"">が</span>お金<span class=""color"">が</span>ない。"	このカメラをかいたいですがおかねがない。	I want to buy this camera, but I have no money..	"恐れ入ります<span class=""color"">が</span>、本日は満席です。"	おそれいれますが、ほんじつはまんせきです。	I deeply apologize, but today we have no more seats available. (we are fully booked)				
11	ga arimasu	があります	there is; is (non-living things)	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td rowspan=""4"">Noun</td><td>がある / があります</td></tr><tr><td>があった / がありました</td></tr><tr><td>がない / がありません</td></tr><tr><td>がなかった / がありませんでした</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"人気<span class=""color"">がある</span>。"	にんきがある。	to be popular.	"先月お金<span class=""color"">が</span>ぜんぜん<span class=""color"">なかった</span>。"	せんげつおかねがぜんぜんなかった。	Last month I had no money.	"へやにテレビ<span class=""color"">があります</span>。"	へやにてれびがあります。	I have a TV in my room.	"日本の好きじゃないところ<span class=""color"">はあります</span>。"	にほんのすきじゃないところはあります。	"There are some things I don't like about Japan."	"このマンションにはへや<span class=""color"">が</span>三つ<span class=""color"">あります</span>。"	このマンションにはへやがみつあります。	There are three rooms in this apartment.	"彼は金<span class=""color"">がある</span>から新車が買える。"	かれはかねがあるからしんしゃがかえる。	He has money so he can buy a new car.	"今夜用事<span class=""color"">がある</span>から行けない。"	こんやようじがあるからいけない。	"I have things to do tonight so I can't go."										
12	ga hoshii	がほしい	to want something	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Noun</td><td>がほしい<br>が欲しい</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"もっとお金<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>です。"	もっとおかねがほしいです。	I want more money.	"彼女<span class=""color"">がほしい</span>。"	かのじょがほしい。	I want a girlfriend.	"お金<span class=""color"">が</span>たくさん<span class=""color"">ほしい</span>。"	おかねがたくさんほしい。	"I want a lot of money. (it's OK to split が and ほしい)"	"何人子ども<span class=""color"">がほしい</span>ですか？"	なんにんこどもがほしいですか？	How many children do you want to have?	"新しいGoProカメラ<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>です！"	あたらしいGoProカメラがほしいです！	I want the new GoPro camera!	"いつか自分の家<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>です。"	いつかじぶんのいえがほしいです。	I want to have my own house one day.	"私<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>ものは自由です。"	わたしがほしいものはじゆうです。	What I want is freedom.	"日本で作られた車<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>。"	にほんでつくられたくるまがほしい。	I want a car made in Japan.	"最近、仕事が忙しすぎてリラックスする時間<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>。"	さいきん、しごとがいそがしすぎてリラックスするじかんがほしい。	Work is too busy lately, I want some time to relax.	"彼が持っているみたいなパソコン<span class=""color"">が欲しい</span>。"	かれがもっているみたいなパソコンがほしい。	I want a computer like the one he has.	
13	ga imasu	がいます	there is; to be; is (living things)	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td rowspan=""4"">Noun</td><td>がいる / がいます</td></tr><tr><td>がいた / がいました</td></tr><tr><td>がいない / がいません</td></tr><tr><td>がいなかった / がいませんでした</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"テーブルの下に猫<span class=""color"">がいる</span>。"	テーブルのしたにねこがいる。	There is a cat below the table.	"あなたは彼氏<span class=""color"">がいる</span>の？"	あなたはかれしがいるの？	Do you have a boyfriend?	"私には兄弟<span class=""color"">がいない</span>んだ。"	わたしにはきょうだいがいないんだ。	"I don't have any siblings."	"弟一人妹一人<span class=""color"">がいます</span>。"	おとうとひとりいもうとひとりがいます。	I have one younger brother and one younger sister.	"その部屋に犬<span class=""color"">がいる</span>。"	そのへやにいぬがいる。	There is a dog in that room.	"今学校<span class=""color"">に</span>だれも<span class=""color"">いません</span>。"	いまがっこうにだれもいません。	There is no one at school right now.	"東京駅に観光者<span class=""color"">が</span>いっぱい<span class=""color"">いる</span>。"	とうきょうえきにかんこうしゃがいっぱいいる。	There are a lot of tourists in Tokyo station.										
14	hou ga ii	ほうがいい	"had better; it'd be better to; should ~"	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb</td><td>方がいい<br>ほうがいい</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"疲れたら、早く寝た<span class=""color"">ほうがいい</span>。"	つかれたら、はやくねたほうがいい。	"If you're tired, it's best to go to bed early."	"暑い日には、水をたくさん飲んだ<span class=""color"">方がいい</span>。"	あついひには、みずをたくさんのんだほうがいい。	"It's best to drink a lot of water on hot days."	"寝る前に、スマホを使わない<span class=""color"">方がいい</span>。"	ねるまえに、スマホをつかわないほうがいい。	"Before going to bed, it's best to not use your smartphone."	"毎日日本語を練習した<span class=""color"">方がいい</span>ですよ。"	まいにちにほんごをれんしゅうしたほうがいいですよ。	You should practice Japanese every day.	"分からないとき、先生に聞いた<span class=""color"">方がいい</span>ですよ。"	わからないとき、せんせいにきいたほうがいいですよ。	"When you don't understand, you're best off asking your teacher."	"肉だけじゃなくて、野菜も食べた<span class=""color"">ほうがいい</span>ですよ。"	にくだけじゃなくて、やさいもたべたほうがいいですよ。	"It's better to not just eat meat, but some vegetables as well."	"ご飯の後で、歯を磨いた<span class=""color"">方がいい</span>ですよ。"	ごはんのあとで、はをみがいたほうがいいですよ。	"It's best to brush your teeth after eating."	"20歳になっても、お酒を飲まない<span class=""color"">方がいい</span>と思います。"	はたちになっても、おさけをのまないほうがいいとおもいます。	"Even if you turn 20, I think it's best to not drink any alcohol."							
15	i-adjectives	い-adjectives	i-adjectives	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>present</td><td>い</td></tr><tr><td>present negative</td><td>くない<br>くありません</td></tr><tr><td>past</td><td>かった</td></tr><tr><td>past negative</td><td>くなかった<br>くありませんでした</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"今日はあつ<span class=""color"">い</span>です。"		It is hot today.	"今日はあつ<span class=""color"">くない</span>です。"		It isn’t hot today.	"昨日はあつ<span class=""color"">かった</span>。"		It was hot yesterday.	"昨日はあつ<span class=""color"">くなかった</span>。"		It was not hot yesterday.																			
16	ichiban	一番（いちばん）	the most; the best	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>[A] + が/は + いちばん</td></tr><tr><td>いちばん + [A]</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"彼<span class=""color"">がいちばん</span>働いた。"	かれがいちばんはたらいた。	He worked the hardest.	"秋<span class=""color"">が一番</span>好きな季節です。"	あきがいちばんすきなきせつです。	Fall is my favorite season.	"私はブロッコリー<span class=""color"">が一番</span>嫌いだ。"	わたしはブロッコリーがいちばんきらいだ。	I hate broccoli the most.	"午前中<span class=""color"">が一番</span>調子がいい。"	ごぜんちゅうがいちばんちょうしがいい。	I feel best in the morning.	"<span class=""color"">一番</span>前に座っている人は誰ですか？"	いちばんまえにすわっているひとはだれですか？	Who is that sitting in the very front?	"<span class=""color"">一番</span>早く予約できる日はいつですか？"	いちばんはやくよやくできるひはいつですか？	When is the earliest day we can make a reservation?	"<span class=""color"">一番</span>美しい花が<span class=""color"">一番</span>早くしおれる。"	いちばんうつくしいはながいちばんはやくしおれる。	The most beautiful flowers are the first to fade.	"兄弟で誰が<span class=""color"">一番</span>背が高いですか。"	きょうだいでだれがいちばんせがたかいですか。	Who is the tallest among your siblings?							
17	issho ni	一緒に（いっしょに）	together	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>often preceded with と</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"<span class=""color"">一緒に</span>日本語を勉強しましょう。"	いっしょににほんごをべんきょうしましょう。	"Let's study Japanese together."	"今夜、カラオケに<span class=""color"">一緒に</span>行こう。"	こんや、カラオケにいっしょにいこう。	"Let's go to karaoke together tonight."	"ずっと彼<span class=""color"">と一緒に</span>いたい。"	ずっとかれといっしょにいたい。	I want to be together with him forever.	"明日の朝、<span class=""color"">一緒に</span>ジムに行きませんか？"	あしたのあさ、いっしょにジムにいきませんか？	Do you want to go to the gym together tomorrow morning?	"今朝、友だち<span class=""color"">と一緒に</span>図書館に行きました。"	けさ、ともだちといっしょにとしょかんにいきました。	I went to the library together with my friend this morning.	"うちの犬<span class=""color"">と一緒に</span>散歩するのが好きです。"	うちのいぬといっしょにさんぽするのがすきです。	"I like walking together with my family's dog."	"来週、家族<span class=""color"">と一緒に</span>富士山を見に行くんだ。"	らいしゅう、かぞくといっしょにふじさんをみにいくんだ。	"Next week I'm going together with my family to see Mt. Fuji."										
18	itsumo	いつも	always; usually; habitually	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Can be used mid-sentence and also to start a new sentence</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"彼は<span class=""color"">いつも</span>元気ですね。"	かれはいつもげんきですね。	He is always energetic.	"妹は<span class=""color"">いつも</span>寝ている。"	いもうとはいつもねている。	My younger sister is always sleeping.	"<span class=""color"">いつも</span>夜10時に寝ます。"	いつもよる１０じにねます。	"I always go to bed at 10 o'clock."	"昼ご飯は<span class=""color"">いつも</span>納豆を食べます。"	ひるごはんはいつもなっとうをたべます。	I always have natto (fermented soybeans) for lunch.	"仕事に行く前に<span class=""color"">いつも</span>ジムに行きます。"	しごとにいくまえにいつもジムにいきます。	I always go to the gym before going to work.	"<span class=""color"">いつも</span>自転車で学校に来ますが今日は歩きました。"	いつもじてんしゃでがっこうにきますがきょうはあるきました。	I always go to school by bike, but today I walked.	"今日は<span class=""color"">いつも</span>と同じ一日だった。"	きょうはいつもとおなじいちにちだった。	Today was a normal day as always.	"君と<span class=""color"">いつも</span>一緒に居たい。"	きみといつもいっしょにいたい。	I want to be together with you always.							
19	janai / dewa nai	じゃない・ではない	to not be (am not; is not; are not)	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>present<br>negative</td><td>casual<br>じゃない<br>ではない<p class=""mt-3 mb-0"">polite</p>じゃありません<br>ではありません</td></tr><tr><td>past<br>negative</td><td>casual<br>じゃなかった<br>ではなかった<p class=""mt-3 mb-0"">polite</p>じゃありませんでした<br>ではありませんでした</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"あなたは一人<span class=""color"">じゃない</span>。"	あなたはひとりじゃない。	You are not alone.	"危険<span class=""color"">じゃない</span>の？"	きけんじゃないの？	"Isn't it dangerous?"	"そんなつもり<span class=""color"">じゃなかった</span>。"	そんなつもりじゃなかった。	"That wasn't my plan/intention."	"ごめんなさい！わざと<span class=""color"">ではありませんでした</span>。"	ごめんなさい！わざとではありませんでした。	"I'm so sorry! It wasn't intentional."	"肉はあまり好き<span class=""color"">じゃない</span>です。"	にくはあまりすきじゃないです。	"I don't really like meat."	"若いころはやさいが好き<span class=""color"">じゃなかった</span>。"	わかいころはやさいがすきじゃなかった。	"I didn't like vegetables when I was younger."	"私は日本語が上手<span class=""color"">ではない</span>。"	わたしはにほんごがじょうずではない。	I am not good at Japanese (language).										
20	ka	か	question particle	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>end of sentence</td><td>か</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"何です<span class=""color"">か</span>？"	なんですか？	What?	"すみません、あなたも学生です<span class=""color"">か</span>。"	すみません、あなたもがくせいですか。	Excuse me, are you also a student?	"あなたの名前は何です<span class=""color"">か</span>。"	あなたのなまえはなんですか。	What is your name?	"元気です<span class=""color"">か</span>。"	げんきですか。	How are you?	"彼は何才です<span class=""color"">か</span>。"	かれはなんさいですか。	How old is he?	"大丈夫です<span class=""color"">か</span>？"	だいじょうぶですか？	Are you alright?	"私とお昼ご飯を食べません<span class=""color"">か</span>？"	わたしとおひるごはんをたべませんか？	Would you like to have lunch with me?	"どうしてこのことを知らないの<span class=""color"">か</span>？"	どうしてこのことをしらないのか？	"Why don't you know about this?"							
21	ka~ka	か～か	or	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb</td><td rowspan=""4"">か</td></tr><tr><td>い-adjective</td></tr><tr><td>な-adjective</td></tr><tr><td>Noun</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"明日は雨<span class=""color"">か</span>どう<span class=""color"">か</span>分からない。"	あしたはあめかどうかわからない。	"I'm not sure if it will rain or not tomorrow."	"お茶<span class=""color"">か</span>コーヒーが飲みたい。"	おちゃかコーヒーがのみたい。	I would like to drink tea or coffee.	"当たる<span class=""color"">か</span>はずれる<span class=""color"">か</span>。"	あたるかはずれるか。	Hit or miss.	"やる<span class=""color"">か</span>やらない<span class=""color"">か</span>早く決めてください。"	やるかやらないかはやくきめてください。	Please hurry up and decide if you are going to do it or not.	"来週の月曜日<span class=""color"">か</span>火曜日に京都に行きます。"	らいしゅうのげつようびかかようびにきょうとにいきます。	"I'm going to Kyoto next Monday or Tuesday."	"死ぬ<span class=""color"">か</span>生きる<span class=""color"">か</span>。"	しぬかいきるか。	Live or die.													
22	kara	から	because; since; from	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><th colspan=""2"" class=""bg-full text-center"">meaning 1: because; since</th></tr><tr><td>Verb</td><td rowspan=""4"">から</td></tr><tr><td>Noun + だ</td></tr><tr><td>な-adjective + だ</td></tr><tr><td>い-adjective + い</td></tr><tr><th colspan=""2"" class=""bg-full text-center"">meaning 2: from; since</th></tr><tr><td>Noun</td><td>から</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"天気がいい<span class=""color"">から</span>、外に行きたい。"	てんきがいいから、そとにいきたい。	Since the weather is nice, I want to go outside.	"私はすぐ戻る<span class=""color"">から</span>、ここでちょっと待ってください。"	わたしはすぐもどるから、ここでちょっとまってください。	"I'll return shortly, so please wait here just a moment."	"これ<span class=""color"">から</span>もよろしくお願いします。"	これからもよろしくおねがいします。	"From now on, let's have a good relationship (I'll be counting on you)."	"ここ<span class=""color"">から</span>あの駅まで歩いてどれぐらいかかりますか？"	ここからあのえきまであるいてどれぐらいかかりますか？	How long does it take to walk from here to that station?	"お店は何時<span class=""color"">から</span>何時まで開いていますか？"	おみせはなんじからなんじまであいていますか？	"What are the shop's opening hours?"																
23	kata	方（かた）	the way of doing something; how to do	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb <s>ます</s> (stem form)</td><td>方<br>かた</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"パソコンの使い<span class=""color"">かた</span>がわかりません。"	パソコンのつかいかたがわかりません。	"I don't know how to use a computer."	"ケーキの作り<span class=""color"">方</span>を知っていますか？"	ケーキのつくりかたをしっていますか？	Do you know how to make a cake?	"おはしの使い<span class=""color"">方</span>が上手ですね。"	おはしのつかいかたがじょうずですね	"You're very good at using chopsticks (you will be told this all the time in Japan)"	"あの先生の教え<span class=""color"">方</span>はとてもわかりやすいです。"	あのせんせいのおしえかたはとてもわかりやすいです。	"That teacher's way of teaching is very easy to understand"	"彼の生き<span class=""color"">方</span>は、かっこいいです。"	かれのいきかたは、かっこいいです。	His way of living is really cool.	"この漢字の読み<span class=""color"">方</span>を教えてください。"	このかんじのよみかたをおしえてください。	Please teach me how to read this kanji character.	"ATMの使い<span class=""color"">方</span>を教えていただけませんか。"	ATMのつかいかたをおしえていただけませんか。	Could you please teach me how to use an ATM?										
24	kedo	けど	but; however; although ~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Use between 2 contradicting ideas</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"仕事は辛い<span class=""color"">けど</span>楽しい。"	しごとはつらいけどたのしい。	Work is tough, but fun.	"金はない<span class=""color"">けど</span>夢はある。"	かねはないけどゆめはある。	"I don't have money, but I have dreams."	"スポーツは上手じゃない<span class=""color"">けど</span>、好きです。"	スポーツはじょうずじゃないけど、すきです。	"I'm not good at sports, but I like them."	"悪い<span class=""color"">けど</span>、明日のパーティーに行けません。"	わるいけど、あしたのパーティーにいけません。	"Sorry, but I can't make it to tomorrow's party."	"眠い<span class=""color"">けど</span>、まだ宿題があるから寝られません。"	ねむいけど、まだしゅくだいがあるからねられません。	"I'm sleepy, but I still have homework to do so I can't go to sleep yet."	"たくさん勉強した<span class=""color"">けど</span>、テストの点はよくないでした。"	たくさんべんきょうしたけど、テストのてんはよくないでした。	"Although I studied a lot, my test score wasn't very good."	"泣いた<span class=""color"">けど</span>後悔はしていません。"	ないたけどこうかいはしていません。	"I cried, but I don't regret it."	"家賃は高い<span class=""color"">けど</span>このマンションが大好きです。"	やちんはたかいけどこのマンションがだいすきです。	The rent is a bit expensive, but I love this apartment.							
25	keredo mo	けれども	but; however; although ~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Use between 2 contradicting ideas</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"このカメラは高かった<span class=""color"">けれど</span>、すぐ壊れてしまいました。"	このカメラはたかかったけれど、すぐこわれてしまいました。	This camera was really expensive, but it broke right away.	"外はさむい<span class=""color"">けれど</span>、家の中は暖かいです。"	そとはさむいけれど、いえのなかはあたたかいです。	It’s cold outside, but inside the house it is warm.	"眠い<span class=""color"">けれど</span>、まだ宿題があるから寝られません。"	ねむいけれど、まだしゅくだいがあるからねられません。	"I'm sleepy but still have homework to do so I can't go to bed yet."	"雪が降っている<span class=""color"">けれども</span>、スーパーに行きます。"	ゆきがふっているけれども、スーパーにいきます。	"Although it is snowing outside, I'm going to the grocery store."	"お金はあまり持っていません。<span class=""color"">けれども</span>、毎日幸せです。"	おかねはあまりもっていません。けれども、まいにちしあわせです。	"I don't have much money.. But every day I am happy."	"先生はクラスでは厳しい<span class=""color"">けれど</span>、クラスの外ではやさしいです。"	せんせいはクラスではきびしいけれど、クラスのそとではやさしいです。	My teacher is really strict in class, but outside of class they are very kind.	"彼は若い<span class=""color"">けれども</span>経験がある。"	かれはわかいけれどもけいけんがある。	"Although he's young, he's got experience."	"列車が遅れた<span class=""color"">けれども</span>、なんとか間に合った。"	れっしゃがおくれたけれども、なんとかまにあった。	Although our train was late we somehow still made it in time.							
26	mada	まだ	still; not yet	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td rowspan=""2"">まだ</td><td>Verb (ている)<br>Verb (ていない)</td></tr><tr><td>Noun</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"<span class=""color"">まだ</span>ですか？"	まだですか？	Is it ready yet? / are we there yet? / Still...?	"<span class=""color"">まだまだ</span>暑いだ。"	まだまだあついだ。	"It's still hot out. (mada can be used twice in a row for extra emphasis)"	"先生は<span class=""color"">まだ</span>来ていない。"	せんせいはまだきていない。	"Our teacher still hasn't come."	"もう10時ですが弟が<span class=""color"">まだ</span>寝ている。"	もうじゅうじですがおとうとがまだねている。	"It's already 10 am, but my younger brother is still sleeping."	"<span class=""color"">まだ</span>1時間もあるよ。"	まだいちじかんもあるよ。	We still have one hour.	"あきらめるのは<span class=""color"">まだ</span>早い！"	あきらめるのはまだはやい！	"It's still too early to give up!"	"私は宿題が<span class=""color"">まだ</span>終わっていません。"	わたしはしゅくだいがまだおわっていません。	"I still haven't finished with my homework."										
27	mada ~te imasen	まだ～ていません	have not yet ~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>まだ</td><td>Verb (てない) *spoken<br>Verb (ていない)<br>Verb (ていません)</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"バスは<span class=""color"">まだ</span>来<span class=""color"">ていません</span>。"	バスはまだきていません。	"The bus still hasn't come."	"<span class=""color"">まだ</span>、決まっ<span class=""color"">ていません</span>。"	まだ、きまっていません。	"It hasn't been decided yet."	"私は<span class=""color"">まだ</span>朝ごはんを食べ<span class=""color"">ていません</span>。"	わたしはまだあさごはんをたべていません。	"I still haven't eaten breakfast yet."	"今週の新しい単語を<span class=""color"">まだ</span>覚え<span class=""color"">ていません</span>。"	こんしゅうのあたらしいたんごをまだおぼえていません。	"I still haven't memorized this week's new vocabulary."	"父は<span class=""color"">まだ</span>帰ってき<span class=""color"">ていない</span>。"	ちちはまだかえってきていない。	"My father still hasn't come home yet."	"<span class=""color"">まだ</span>宿題をやっ<span class=""color"">ていない</span>。"	まだしゅくだいをやっていない。	"I haven't done my homework yet."	"<span class=""color"">まだ</span>明日締め切りのレポートが終わっ<span class=""color"">てない</span>ので、遊びに行けない。"	まだあしたしめきりのレポートがおわってないので、あそびにいけない。	"I haven't finished my report due tomorrow yet, so I can't go out today."	"俺は<span class=""color"">まだ</span>あきらめ<span class=""color"">てない</span>んだぞ。"	おれはまだあきらめてないんだぞ。	"I haven't given up yet!"	"私の知っている限りでは、彼女は<span class=""color"">まだ</span>結婚し<span class=""color"">ていません</span>。"	わたしのしっているかぎりでは、かのじょはまだけっこんしていません。	"As far as I know she's still not married."				
28	made	まで	until; as far as; to (an extent); even ~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Noun</td><td>まで</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"<span class=""color"">昨日まで</span>お休みでした。"	きのうまでおやすみでした。	I was on vacation until yesterday.	"ここから<span class=""color"">そこまで</span>は遠いですよ。"	ここからそこまではとおいですよ。	"That's really far from here!"	"駅<span class=""color"">まで</span>行きたいんですが、どう行ったらいいですか。"	えきまでいきたいんですが、どういったらいいですか。	How can I get to the station?	"<span class=""color"">最後まで</span>がんばってね！"	さいごまでがんばってね！	Do your best all the way until the end!	"<span class=""color"">家まで</span>車で送ります。"	いえまでくるまでおくります。	"I'll take you home by car."	"朝から<span class=""color"">夜まで</span>ずっとかんじを勉強しました。"	あさからよるまでずっとかんじをべんきょうしました。	I studied kanji all day from morning until night.	"お店は何時から何時<span class=""color"">まで</span>開いていますか？"	おみせはなんじからなんじまであいていますか？	"What are the shop's opening hours?"	"先生、何時<span class=""color"">まで</span>学校にいらっしゃいますか。"	せんせい、なんじまでがっこうにいらっしゃいますか。	Teacher, until what time will you be at school?	"昼ごはん<span class=""color"">まで</span>にレポートを書いてしまいました。"	ひるごはんまでにレポートをかいてしまいます。	I kept writing my report until lunch.	"雨が降っているよ。駅<span class=""color"">まで</span>送ってあげようか？"	あめがふっているよ。えきまでおくってあげようか？	"It's raining.. Shall I give you a lift to the station?"	
29	mae ni	前に（まえに）	before; in front of~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (dictionary form)</td><td rowspan=""2"">前に<br>まえに</td></tr><tr><td>Noun + の</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"ドアを開ける<span class=""color"">前に</span>ノックぐらいしてください。"	ドアをあけるまえにノックぐらいしてください。	Before opening the door, please at least knock first.	"コンビニ<span class=""color"">の前に</span>じてんしゃがたくさんあります。"	こんびにのまえにじいてんしゃがたくさんあります。	There are many bicycles in front of the convenience store.	"旅行<span class=""color"">の前に</span>切符を買っておきます。"	りょこうのまえにきっぷをかっておきます。	I will buy the tickets before the trip.	"ご飯<span class=""color"">の前に</span>手を洗いましょう。"	ごはんのまえにてをあらいましょう。	"let's make sure to wash our hands before eating."	"テスト<span class=""color"">の前に</span>一生懸命勉強しました。"	てすとのまえにいっしょうけんめいべんきょうしました。	I studied like crazy before the test.	"大学を卒業する<span class=""color"">前に</span>留学したいな。"	だいがくをそつぎょうするまえにりゅうがくしたいな。	I really want to study abroad sometime before I graduate university.	"23時<span class=""color"">前に</span>寝なければなりません。"	23じまえにねなければなりません。	I need to go to bed before 11pm.	"寝る<span class=""color"">前に</span>、歯みがきを忘すれないでね。"	ねるまえに、はみがきをわすれないでね。	"Don't forget to brush your teeth before you go to bed."	"試合<span class=""color"">の前に</span>まだ一週間があるのでもっと練習しょう。"	しあいのまえにまだいっしゅうかんがあるのでもっとれんしゅうしょう。	"We still have a week to go before the game so let's practice some more."	"私たちの学校<span class=""color"">の前に</span>は美しい公園があります。"	わたしたちのがっこうのまえにはうつくしいこうえんがあります。	There is a beautiful park in front of our school.	
30	masen ka	ませんか	would you; do you want to; shall we ~	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (polite negative) + か<br>ません + か</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"今日一緒に食べ<span class=""color"">ませんか</span>？"	きょういっしょにたべませんか？	Do you want to eat together today?	"うちで映画を見<span class=""color"">ませんか</span>。"	うちでえいがをみませんか。	Do you want to watch a movie at my place?	"お茶にし<span class=""color"">ません</span>か？"	おちゃにしませんか？	Would you care for some tea?	"日曜日にテニスをし<span class=""color"">ません</span>か。"	にちようびにテニスをしませんか。	Do you want to play tennis on Sunday?	"明日自転車で学校へ行き<span class=""color"">ません</span>か？"	あしたじてんしゃでがっこうへいきませんか？	Do you want to go to school tomorrow by bike?	"もう暗くなりました。家へ帰り<span class=""color"">ません</span>か。"	もうくらくなりました。いえへかえりませんか。	"It's gotten dark already.. Shall we head home?"	"写真をとっ<span class=""color"">てくれません</span>か？"	しゃしんをとってくれませんか？	Would you mind taking a photo?	"私の仕事を手伝っ<span class=""color"">てくれません</span>か。"	わたしのしごとをてつだってくれませんか。	Would you mind helping me with my work?							
31	mashou	ましょう	"let's ~; shall we ~"	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb <s>ます</s> (stem form)</td><td>ましょう</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"行き<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>！"	いきましょう！	"Let's go!"	"駅で会い<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>！"	えきであいましょう！	"Let's meet at the station!"	"もうご飯の時間だよ、早く食べ<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>！"	もうごはんのじかんだよ、はやくたべましょう！	"It's already dinner time, let's hurry up and eat!"	"帰る前に教室をきれいにし<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>。"	かえるまえにきょうしつをきれいにしましょう。	"Before we go home, let's clean up the classroom."	"一緒に日本語を勉強し<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>！"	いっしょににほんごをべんきょうしよう！	"Let's study Japanese together!"	"もう暗くなったから、帰り<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>。"	もうくらくなったから、かえりましょう。	"It's gotten dark already, so let's head home."	"来週、すしを食べに行き<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>よ！"	らいしゅう、すしをたべにいきましょうよ。	"Let's go out to eat some sushi next week!"	"10時になったら、出かけ<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>。"	10じになったら、でかけましょう。	"Let's head out at 10 o'clock."	"電気をつけて、部屋を明るくし<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>。"	でんきをつけて、へやをあかるくしましょう。	"Let's turn on the lights and make the room brighter."	"決める前にもっとデータを収集し<span class=""color"">ましょう</span>。"	きめるまえにもっとデータをしゅうしゅうしましょう。	"Before we decide, let's gather some more data."	
32	mashouka	ましょうか	shall I ~; used to offer help to the listener	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb <s>ます</s> (stem form)</td><td>ましょうか</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"マドを開け<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>。"	まどをあけましょうか。	Shall I open the window?	"手伝い<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>。"	てつだいましょうか。	Do you want some help?	"荷物を持ち<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>。"	にもつをもちましょうか。	Shall I help carry your luggage?	"タクシーを呼び<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>。"	タクシーをよびましょうか。	Shall I call a taxi for you?	"私がお皿を洗い<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>？"	わたしがおさらをあらいましょうか？	Shall I wash the dishes?	"写真を取り<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>。"	しゃしんをとりましょうか。	Shall I take a picture for you?	"サラダを作り<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>？"	サラダをつくりましょうか？	Shall I make a salad?	"次回の会合は来週にし<span class=""color"">ましょうか</span>？それとも再来週の方がいいですか？"	じかいのかいごうはらいしゅうにしましょうか？それともさらいしゅうのほうがいいですか？	For the next meeting, shall we meet next week, or 2 weeks from now?							
33	mo	も	too; also; as well	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Noun + も</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"私<span class=""color"">も</span>できる。"	わたしもできる。	I can do that too.	"甘いもの<span class=""color"">も</span>辛いもの<span class=""color"">も</span>好きです。"	あまいものもからいものもすきです。	I like sweets as well as spicy foods.	"カラオケにはみんなが来ました。先生<span class=""color"">も</span>来ました。"	カラオケにはみんながきました。せんせいもきました。	Everyone came to sing karaoke. Our teacher came too.	"私は日本語<span class=""color"">も</span>英語<span class=""color"">も</span>ベトナム語<span class=""color"">も</span>話せます。"	わたしはにほんごもえいごもべとなむごもはなせます。	I can speak English, Japanese, as well as Vietnamese.	"あなた<span class=""color"">も</span>お腹が空いたでしょう？"	あなたもおなかがすいたでしょう？	"You are probably hungry too, aren't you?"	"私<span class=""color"">も</span>日本語を勉強していますよ！"	わたしもにほんごをべんきょうしていますよ！	"I'm studying Japanese too!"	"私の妻<span class=""color"">も</span>子ども<span class=""color"">も</span>来ます。"	わたしのつまもこどももきます。	My wife and children will come too.	"私<span class=""color"">も</span>日本で留学したことがあります。"	わたしもにほんでりゅうがくしたことがあります。	"I've also studied abroad in Japan before."	"仕事に行くとき、自転車<span class=""color"">も</span>電車<span class=""color"">も</span>使っています。"	しごとにいくとき、じてんしゃもでんしゃもつかっています。	When I go to work I use both my bike and the train.				
34	mou	もう	already; anymore; again; other	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>See examples below</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"<span class=""color"">もう</span>昼ご飯の時間だ。早く食べましょう！"	もうひるごはんのじかんだ。はやくたべましょう！	"It's lunch time already, let's hurry up and eat." "飲み物は全部飲みました。<span class=""color"">もう</span>ありません。"	のみものはぜんぶのみました。もうありません。	"We drank all of the drinks. There aren't any left." "<span class=""color"">もう</span>この暑さには、耐えられない。"	もうこのあつかには、たえられない。	"I can't handle this heat anymore."	"<span class=""color"">もう</span>我慢できない。"	もうがまんできない。	"I can't take it anymore."	"<span class=""color"">もう</span>10時ですが、彼はまだ寝ています。"	もう10じですが、かれはまだねています。	"It's already 10 o'clock, but he's still sleeping." 35	na-adjectives	な-adjectives	na-adjectives	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>present</td><td>な / だ</td></tr><tr><td>present negative</td><td>じゃない<br>ではない</td></tr><tr><td>past</td><td>だった<br>でした</td></tr><tr><td>past negative</td><td>じゃなかった<br>ではありませんでした</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"その子は<span class=""color"">げんきだ</span>。"		That child is energetic.	"かれは<span class=""color"">げんきな</span>子だね。"		He is an energetic child.	"その子は<span class=""color"">げんきじゃない</span>ね。"		That child is not very energetic.	"その子はとても<span class=""color"">げんきだった</span>ね。"		That child was really energetic.	"かれはあまり<span class=""color"">げんきじゃなかった</span>ね。"		He wasn’t very energetic.																
36	naa	なあ	sentence ending particle; confirmation; admiration, etc	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>end of sentence + な(あ)</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"たくさんの人がいる<span class=""color"">なあ</span>。"	たくさんのひとがいるなあ。	"Wow, there's a lot of people here."	"これ、美味しい<span class=""color"">なあ</span>。"	これ、おいしいなあ。	This is really delicious.	"暑くなってきた<span class=""color"">なあ</span>。"	あつくなってきたなあ。	"It's starting to get hotter."	"それは本当か<span class=""color"">な</span>。"	それはほんとうかな。	"I wonder if that's true..."	"明日は晴れる<span class=""color"">かなあ</span>。"	あしたははれるかなあ。	I wonder if the weather will clear up tomorrow...	"トイレはどこ<span class=""color"">かな</span>。"	トイレはどこかな。	I wonder where the restroom is...	"頭が痛い<span class=""color"">な</span>。"	あたまがいたいな。	"I've got a headache..."	"新し自転車が欲しい<span class=""color"">な～</span>。"	あたらしいじてんしゃがほしいなあ。	I really want a new bicycle...	"あなたは全部一人で作りましたか？すごい<span class=""color"">なあ</span>！"	あなたはぜんぶひとりでつくりましたか？すごいなあ！	"You made all of this by yourself? That's too awesome!"				
37	naide	ないで	without doing~ ; To do [B] without doing [A]	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (ない form) + で</td><td>2nd action</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"コーヒーには、いつもさとうを入れ<span class=""color"">ないで</span>飲みます。"	コーヒーには、いつもさとうをいれないでのみます。	I always drink coffee without putting any sugar in it.	"彼女はカサを持た<span class=""color"">ないで</span>出てしまった。"	かのじょはかさをもたないででてしまった。	She left without bringing an umbrella.	"昨日は疲れていて、電気を消さ<span class=""color"">ないで</span>寝てしまった。"	きのうはつかれていて、でんきをけさないでねてしまった。	Yesterday I was so tired I fell asleep without turning off the lights.	"今朝、朝ごはんを食べ<span class=""color"">ないで</span>仕事に来ました。"	けさ、あさごはんをたべないでしごとにきました	I came to work today without eating any breakfast.	"昨日、お風呂に入ら<span class=""color"">ないで</span>寝てしまった。"	きのう、おふろにはいらないでねてしまった。	I went to bed yesterday without taking a bath/shower.	"明日は試験なので、今夜は寝<span class=""color"">ないで</span>勉強します。"	あしたはしけんなので、こんやはねないでべんきょうします。	"Tomorrow is test day, so I'm gonna stay up all night and study without sleep."	"最近、涼しいのでエアコンをつけ<span class=""color"">ないで</span>寝ます。"	さいきん、すずしいのでエアコンをつけないでねます。	"Lately it's pretty cool, so I go to sleep without using the AC."	"朝ごはんを食べ<span class=""color"">ないで</span>学校に来たから、お腹がすいた。"	あさごはんをたべないでがっこうにきたから、おなかがすいた。	"I came to school without eating breakfast, so I'm pretty hungry."							
38	naide kudasai	ないでください	"please don't do"	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (ない form) + で</td><td>ください</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"泣か<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	なかないでください。	"Please don't cry."	"このパソコンを使わ<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	このパソコンをつかわないでください。	"Please don't use this computer."	"明日の予定を忘れ<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	あしたのよていをわすれないでください。	"Don't forget about our plans tomorrow!"	"私のことを心配し<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	わたしのことをしんぱいしないでください。	"Please don't worry about me."	"道の邪魔をし<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	みちのじゃまをしないでください。	"Please don't block the street."	"事務所で食べ<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	じむしょでたべないでください。	"Please don't eat in the office."	"一人にしたいからここに来<span class=""color"">ないでください</span>。"	ひとりにしたいからここにこないでください。	"I want to be alone, so please don't come over here."										
39	naito ikenai	ないといけない	must do; have an obligation to do	"<table class=""table table-bordered table-sm usage""><tbody><tr><td>Verb (ない form) + と</td><td>いけない<br>いけません<br>ダメです</td></tr></tbody></table>"	5	"そろそろ寝<span class=""color"">ないといけない</span>。"	そろそろねないといけない。	I have to sleep soon.	"私は家に帰ら<span class=""color"">ないといけない</span>。"	わたしはいえにかえらないといけない。	I have to go home.	"今から勉強をし<span class=""color"">ないといけない</span>。"	いまからべんきょうをしないといけない。	I have to study now.	"明日から働か<span class=""color"">ないといけない</span>。"	あしたからはたらかないといけない。	I have to work from tomorrow.	"この薬を飲ま<span class=""color"">ないといけませんか</span>。"	このくすりをのまないといけませんか？	Do I have to take this medicine?	"私は今から仕事を始め<span class=""color"">ないといけません</span>。"	わたしはいまからしごとをはじめないといけません。	I must start my work now.	"私は17時ごろ家に帰ら<span class=""color"">ないといけません</span>。"	わたしは17じごろいえにかえらないといけません。	I have to go home at 5PM.	"もっと勉強し<span class=""color"">ないとだめです</span>よね。"	もっとべんきょうしないとだめですよね。	"So I have to study more, don't I?"

雚	Pegasus	611.1				Turkey with wings is a Pegasus

广	Cave	631.1					
㣺	Valentine	682.1				This is a primitive derived from heart (心). This derived form is always at the very bottom.	
忄	(Emotional) State of mind	665.1				This is a primitive form of (心) when it is on the left.
